libstegan module¶

A small helper library for tinfoilmsg which handles the image and text transformations. The dictionary which is supposed to be passed to these functions and classes can look like this: {

‘red’: True, ‘green’: False, ‘blue’: True, ‘frequency’: 3

} This will tell them that only red and blue channels are interesting, and pixels on positions dividable by 3 in particular.

class libstegan.PixelIterator(conf_dict, image)[source]¶

Bases: object

An object to be iterated over. Returns 3-tuples which consist of a channel and x, y coordinates. Currently supports only 1:1 image ratio.

libstegan._craft_pixel(color, message, msg_pointer)[source]¶

Returns a RGB tuple inside which there is or there is not a letter.

libstegan._decode_worker(pixel_info, pixel_rgb)[source]¶

Receives two tuples containing information about a pixel: its RGB values and channel info from PixelIterator. Returns a letter or an empty string.

libstegan._generate_dimensions(conf_dict, message)[source]¶

Returns a 2-tuple consisting of width and height of an image which has no less than _minimal_pixel_count pixels. Only 1:1 ratio for now.

libstegan._minimal_pixel_count(conf_dict, message)[source]¶

Calculates the minimal amount of pixels needed to encode the message.

libstegan._random_color()[source]¶

Does exactly what it is supposed to do.

libstegan._validate_ascii(message)[source]¶

Ensure that the message provided is composed of ASCII letters only, it’s crucial since it will be mapped to RGB values which can’t exceed 255.

libstegan.decode(conf_dict, image)[source]¶

Extracts the message hidden in the image, according to the rules from conf_dict. Returns the message string. Uses multiprocessing.Pool under the hood.

libstegan.encode(conf_dict, message)[source]¶

Converts the message to an image, according to the rules provided in conf_dict. Returns an image file.

tinfoilmsg
